text: This is a download from BBC Learning English to find out more, visit our website.
6MtEnglish from BBCLearningEnglish.com
Hello, I'm Neil and welcome to 6 Minute English, where we vigorously discuss a new topic
speaker: Neil

text: and six related items of vocabulary. And hello, I'm Rob. Today, we're discussing
vigorous exercise and whether adults take enough of it. Vigorous means using a lot of energy
to do something. So how many steps do you do in a day, Rob? How many steps? How should I know,
Neil? It will be pretty hard to count them all. Come on, you can track steps on your phone.
I do 10,000 a day, which is the magic number for keeping fit and healthy apparently.
Not if you sawn to Neil, surely. Sauntering from the sofa to the fridge and back, or
from the house to the car. Well, I never sawn to a rob. Sauntur means to walk slowly,
and you'd have to make a lot of trips to the fridge to clock up 10,000 steps. To get some vigorous
exercise, you need to get out and about. Round the park at a brisk pace. Brisk means quick and energetic,
speaker: Saunter

text: the opposite of sauntering. Okay, well, perhaps you can tell me, Neil, how many people aged between
40 and 60 do less than 10 minutes brisk walking every month? Is it a 4%? B 14% or C 40%.
I'm going to say 4%, because 10 minutes is such a short amount of time.
Indeed. Now, I've got another question for you, Neil. Why is exercise so important? Because
speaker: Neil

text: it sounds pretty boring, counting steps, going to the gym, running on a machine. Well,
when you exercise, you stimulate the body's natural repair system. Your body will actually stay younger
speaker: Neil

text: if you exercise. That sounds good. Exercise also lowers your risk of developing illnesses,
such as heart disease, cancer, and diabetes. Hmm. I’m getting a bit worried now, Neil
speaker: Neil

text: but I don't have enough time to do a thousand steps every day. I'm far too busy.
Well, Rob. Now might be a good time to listen to Julia Bradbury. She’s a TV presenter and
speaker: Neil

text: outdoor walking enthusiast who will explain how she builds walking into her busy life.
I will walk to meetings instead of catching a bus or getting a taxi or a car into meetings.
speaker: INSERT

text: And I will also, if I can't build that into my working day, if it's a day when I haven't got
meetings, I'm maybe at home with the kids, I will take the time, I will take my kids out with the
buggy and I will definitely do 30, 40 minutes, at least every day, going to the park, going to the
shops, picking up my things on route and really sort of building it into my life, taking the stairs
and not taking lifts. All of these kinds of little decisions can intremently build up to creating
more walking time in your day. So, if you build something into your day or your life,
you include it from the beginning. And Julia Bradbury has built walking into her day,
even though she's very busy too, Rob, you should learn from her. So she walks instead of driving
speaker: Neil

text: or taking the bus and takes the stairs instead of the lift. Hmm, I could do those things. You could
indeed, before you know it, you'd be doing 10,000 steps because the amount of walking you do in a day
builds incrementally. Incrementally means gradually increasing in size. Okay, well, before I think
that over, perhaps I could tell you the answer to today's quiz question. Okay, you asked me how many
people age between 40 and 60 do less than 10 minutes brisk walking every month? The options were
and you said 4% but I'm afraid it's actually 40% and that's according to the government body
speaker: Neil

text: public health England here in the UK. Oh dear, that's a lot more people than I expected
but it isn't that surprising. People in all age groups are leading more sedentary lifestyles these
speaker: sedentary

text: days. Our job is very sedentary which means it involves a lot of sitting and not much exercise.
Well, I might just run on the spot while we go with the new vocabulary we've learned today.
Good plan. First up, we heard vigorous which means using a lot of energy to do something.
speaker: Neil

text: Okay, I'm running vigorously on the spot. Great example. And good to see you taking some vigorous
exercise. Number two, saunter means to walk slowly in a relaxed way. When I saw Rob, I sauntered
speaker: Neil

text: over to say hello. Hi Neil. Number three, brisk means quick and energetic. It's important to take
some brisk exercise every day. Yes, and I'm beginning to realise that that might be true.
Yep, I think you've done enough jogging for today, Rob. You've probably done about a hundred steps.
speaker: Rob

text: Oh, is that all? Okay, number four, if you build something into something, you include it from
the beginning. It's important to build regular exercise into your daily routine. Very good advice.
Number five is incrementally which means gradually increasing in size.
speaker: Neil

text: Incremental is the adjective. “The company has been making incremental changes to its pay structure
speaker: Neil

text: Does that mean we're getting a pay rise? I doubt it. And finally, number six, sedentary means
sitting a lot and not taking much exercise. For example, it's bad for your health to lead such a
speaker: Neil

text: sedentary lifestyle. Ah, do you really know, did Neil? Well, it's time to go now, but if today's
show has inspired you to step out and take more exercise, please let us know by visiting our Twitter,
Facebook and YouTube pages and telling us all about it. Goodbye. Bye-bye.
